newsitem.title: UK: FEATURE - Technology pretenders see millennium bug opportunity.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Technology pretenders see millennium bug opportunity.

text.p: By Neil Winton, Science and Technology Correspondent
While industrialised nations nervously await fallout from the millennium computer bug, developing countries can afford to be a little smug.
Technology leaders like the United States are the most exposed to computer failure, but some emerging countries are likely to prevail for two reasons.
They are too poor to have "modernised" their industries with computers and therefore don't fear any catastrophic failure as clocks tick past midnight on December 31, 1999.
And many countries like India and Ukraine have invested heavily in training computer specialists who can make fortunes helping to sort out the problems for western companies.
At the end of 1999 many computers will either crash, or start pumping out erroneous data because of shortcuts taken by programmers in the 1970s and 1980s.

Programmers tried to save computer memory by abbreviating years to "81" or "97". But as the next century dawns, this short cut will explode inside many computers when they read the year 2000 as a meaningless 00.
INDUSTRIALISED NATIONS BIG MILLENNIUM BUG LOSERS
Not surprisingly countries and industries which invested most in computers will suffer the most from any failures. They will have to spend heavily to fix the problem.

"Although the Year 2000 problem is of global concern, it is starting to appear that the most heavily industrialised and computer-intensive countries are going to bear the brunt of the expenses -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain and Brazil will probably be the most heavily impacted," said a report by Capers Jones, chairman of Software Productivity Research (SPR), a research firm based in Burlington, Massachusetts.
Jones said crashing company computers could isolate businesses from customers, freeze cash flow, and inevitably lead to the demise of some firms.
Some business sectors were particularly vulnerable.

"The industries most likely to be affected are those that utilise software for key business operations: banks, brokers, health care, insurance, manufacturing, retail, wholesale. All of these probably have a two percent chance of going out of business or declaring bankruptcy to stave off damages and litigation," Jones said.
"Some business failure will probably occur, especially among mid-sized financial and insurance companies which have lagged in beginning Year 2000 repairs," Jones said.
LOCAL, NATIONAL GOVERNMENTS LOOK VULNERABLE
"Perhaps the most hazardous of any of these is not an industry at all, but the effect of the Year 2000 problem on state, provincial, country and city government operations," Jones said.
Experts in Europe have similar worries.

Robin Guenier, executive director of Britain's Taskforce 2000, doesn't believe there will be catastrophic breakdowns from the millennium bug, but fears a creeping fracture of civilised society from an accumulation of small problems.
"We don't see major disasters on 2000, we're not going to see nuclear power stations blowing up or planes falling out of the sky," Guenier said.

"I fear a series of incremental problems nibbling at the infrastructure. Social security payments being calculated wrongly, intermittent failure of power supplies, railway breakdowns, and some food and commodity shortages.
"There really could be a social crisis if this begins to happen. People will get angry and point to those at the top and say 'Why is this happening'," Guenier said.
INDIA, CHINA EYE U.S. SOFTWARE LEADERSHIP
While trouble brews in the West, unlikely pretenders will be gearing up.
"A possible outcome of the Year 2000 problem is that the United States will lose its dominant market position in the software industry," SPR's Jones said.

"Countries such as India, China, Russia, and Ukraine will gain market share since they are not as heavily impacted by Year 2000 work, and will have a substantial surplus of software technical personnel while the U.S. enters a period of shortage."
Millennium bug problems won't just cluster around New Year's day, 2000.
There is the leap year date in February, and later in the year on the 10th October, 2000, computers will have to handle the first 10 digit date.
Jones said expense and disruption will persist for years, as repairs fail, fixes themselves induce breakdowns, and law suits fly.
EMU PREPARATIONS CRIPPLE EUROPE'S BUG PLANS
In Europe, pressure to repair software for 2000 is hampered by demand for programmers to prepare for monetary union. EMU can be postponed but 2000 can't.

"Europe is concentrating on EMU rather than 2000. All computer projects come in late and over budget and under specification, and coming in late for 2000 is not a very good idea," said Anthony Parish, director general of Britain's Federation of the Electronics Industry.
Taskforce 2000's Guenier is also worried about EMU's impact.
"We are very bad at doing projects on time and to do two at the same time is astonishingly daring. 1999 is the worst possible year to pick (for EMU)," Guenier said.
